In order to select appropriate stimuli and examine properties of our translation of DES, we conducted a pre-test. Participants were recruited via social media and were aimed to have similar demographic characteristics to the planned main sample. We acquired data from 49 participants (41 women, Mage = 22.49, SD = 3.45).
 The pre-test Internet survey contained our translation of DES and 23 images depicting unpleasant food, which were rated by participants for disgust (and exploratorily for edibility) on 5-point Likert-type scales from 1 - no disgust at all to 5 - extreme disgust (and from 1 - completely inedible to 5 - completely edible). The pictures were also rated for valence and arousal on 9-point Self-Assessment Manikin (SAM) scales, in which the numbers corresponded to pictures showing manikins in emotional states of different intensity from 1 of low intensity to 9 of high intensity. SAM scales were included because they are typically used in IAPS pictures assessment (Bradley & Lang, 2007; Lang, Bradley, & Cuthbert, 2008). Other pictures that we are planning to use are from the IAPS database (1111, 1274, 3019, 9008 9031, 9043, 9290, 9300, 9302, 9322, 9340, 9373) and were examined for their disgust-inducing properties in other studies (Borg, Jong, & Schultz, 2010; Van Hooff, Devue, Vieweg, & Theeuwes, 2013). Finally, participants were asked for demographic information.
From the 23 food pictures, 12 pictures with highest mean disgust ratings were selected for the main study. Our food stimuli mean disgust rating was M = 2.34 on the 5-point scale and the ratings ranged from M = 2.29 to M = 3.88 meaning that they were slightly to moderately disgusting. They were descriptively less disgusting than the pictures from IAPS that we are planning to use as general disgust stimuli. In Van Hooff et al.’s (2013) study the latter were rated on average as very disgusting: M = 4.03 on a similar 5-point scale. This is understandable as our pictures were showing “only” partly rotten food or food with insects on it and the pictures in Van Hooff were showing, for example, bloody organs or dirty toilets.
Our food pictures’ mean valence ranged from M = 1.92 to M = 3.12 on the 9-point SAM scale meaning that they were perceived as unpleasant. The selected disgusting food stimuli’s valence seems comparable to the general disgust stimuli selected from the IAPS, mean valence of which ranged from M = 2.24 to M = 3.38 on a similar scale in previous studies (Lang et al., 2008). Mean arousal of our food stimuli ranged from M = 2.98 to M = 5.20 on the 9-point scale, which means the pictures evoked low to medium arousal and were descriptively less arousing than the selected pictures from the IAPS used in previous disgust studies where mean arousal ranged from M = 4.40 to M = 6.30 (Lang et al., 2008).
The food pictures were also exploratorily examined on perceived edibility. The 12 pictures selected on the basis of disgust ratings were rated as, on average, inedible, M = 1.70 on a 5-point scale, ratings ranging from M = 1.14 to M = 2.36.
	The translated DES’s reliability was satisfactory with a Cronbach’s α = 0.76 for the whole scale. The subscales’ reliability ranged from α = 0.67 (Animals) to α = 0.91 (Rotting Food). 
Participants’ disgust sensitivity measured by DES was moderately positively correlated with reported disgust elicited by the pictures, r = 0.62. Rotting Food and Smell subscales’ relation to disgust evoked by the pictures was, r = 0.71 and r = 0.56, respectively. 
	In conclusion, the pre-test allowed to select stimuli for the main study, to acknowledge the translated Disgust Emotion Scale as satisfactorily reliable and to observe an expected correlation of DES and pictures evaluation.

question.value:
We plan to acquire data from 60 participants with normal or corrected-to-normal vision: 30 freegans and 30 non-freegans with similar demographic characteristics. As the studied group is very specific and not publicly visible, participants will be recruited via social media groups, snowballing and personal contacts. The study will take place in the laboratory of psychophysiology at the Faculty of Psychology, University of Warsaw and is planned to last about 30 minutes. On entering the lab participants will sign an informed consent. Then they will have their skin prepared and electrodes placed. They will be seated in front of a computer screen. The programmed procedure will start after the experimenter leaves the room.
Participants will have activity of Corrugator supercilii and Levator labii measured with EMG, while watching on a computer screen 12 disgust-inducing pictures from IAPS (International Affective Picture System; Lang, Bradley, & Cuthbert, 2008) and 12 pictures showing unattractive food. The latter were pre-tested for their disgust-inducing properties (see the Pre-test and selection of stimuli section above). The pictures will be presented in random order, using MediaLab software. Each of the pictures will be preceded by a three- or six-second fixation mark and displayed for 6 seconds. Silver-silver chloride (Ag-AgCl) surface electrodes will be used, with 0.25 cm diameter detection surfaces and 1 cm diameter housings. As Fridlund and Cacioppo (1986) recommend, the space between two electrodes in a pair will be about 1 cm. The electrodes measuring Corrugator supercilii activity will be placed above the brow: one on an imaginary vertical line above the inner corner of the eye and the other lateral and slightly superior to the first. The electrodes measuring Levator labii activity will be situated 1 cm lateral to the nostril baseline: one 0.5 cm below the nostril and the other superior and slightly lateral to the first. Ground electrode, with 0.5 cm diameter detection surface and 1.5 cm diameter housing, will be located in the middle of the forehead (Fridlund, Cacioppo, 1986). Electrodes, glaired with EEG gel, will be placed on cleaned skin. Impedances, examined using portable impedance checker, should not be higher than 10 kΩ.
	Besides of the EMG measurement, participants will rate how much disgusted they feel about each of the pictures from 1 - no disgust at all to 5 - extreme disgust.
	Second task will be to complete Disgust Emotion Scale (DES; Olatunji et al., 2006) in Polish translation, which has been examined in a pilot study and (for freegan participants) a Polish adaptation of Identification Scale adjusted to freegans (Cameron, 2004; general Polish adaptation by Bilewicz & Wójcik, 2010). Freegan participants will also be asked how long they have been freegans, how often they go dumpster diving and how many times approximately they went dumpster diving. Furthermore, they will be asked questions concerning quality and intensity of freegan experience and motivations for dumpster diving. In the non-freegans’ case, the open-ended question will concern their knowledge and interest in freeganism.
Then they will be presented 7 pictures from IAPS showing young animals, aiming to abreact the exposure to previous unpleasant stimuli. After the programmed procedure will end, they will call the experimenter and have the electrodes removed. Finally, they will be debriefed about the aims of the study and thanked for participation.

q14.value: To achieve statistical power at the level of 0,8 with alpha error rate = 0,05, sample size of 63 participants was calculated using powerandsamplesize.com.

question.value:
Both general and food disgust sensitivity will be assessed with three measures: two declarative and one psychophysiological (EMG; described in the Data collection procedures section). The declarative measures will include pictures ratings from 1 - no disgust at all to 5 - extreme disgust and results on Disgust Emotion Scale (DES; Olatunji et al., 2006 in our pretested translation). DES consists of 30 items pertaining to five subscales. The instruction is to rate how much disgust one would feel if exposed to a given item, e.g. ‘Photos of wounded soldiers’, ‘A pile of rotting lettuce’. The responses are given on 5-point Likert-type scale from 1 - no disgust at all to 5 - extreme disgust.
General disgust sensitivity will be indicated by the result on three non-food-related subscales of DES: Animals,  Injections and Blood Draws, Mutilation and Death; ratings of disgust-inducing pictures and Corrugator supercilii and Levator labii reactions to disgust-inducing pictures. Correspondingly, food disgust sensitivity will be indicated by the result in Rotting Food and Smell subscales of DES, ratings of pictures showing unattractive food and Corrugator supercilii and Levator labii reactions to pictures showing unattractive food.
	Experience with freeganism will be measured with a yes/no question, filtering the subsequent questions. Freegans’ in-group identification will be measured with the Identification Scale adjusted to freegans (Cameron, 2004; general Polish adaptation by Bilewicz & Wójcik, 2010). The scale comprises 6 items (sample item: ‘I feel strong ties to other [ingroup members]’). The responses are given on 5-point Likert-type scale from 1 - strongly disagree to 5 - strongly agree.
Freegans’ experience in dumpster diving will be investigated with questions about: declared time since starting (in months), frequency (how many times per month) and number of dumpster diving experiences, the type of containers frequented, kinds of food taken and usage of gloves. Their motivation for freeganism will be explored with an open-ended question about how and why they started dumpster diving. Non-freegans will be asked an open-ended question about their knowledge what freeganism is and whether they would be willing to try it, instead.
	We will also control age, gender, education, place of residence (urban or rural) and political orientation (one-item seven-point scale from 1 - strongly left-wing to 7 - strongly right-wing).

In order to examine the H1, we will compare freegans’ and non-freegans’ results in DES and its subscales, their pictures ratings and their Corrugator and Levator activity. ANCOVA will be used for each measure, controlling for demographic variables.
	To examine whether food disgust decreases with gaining freegan experience (H2) we will investigate correlations between measures of experience and DES Rotting Food and Smell subscales, pictures ratings and Corrugator and Levator activity.
	To test the H3, Pearson correlations will be calculated to examine the relations between in-group identification and disgust sensitivity measured by DES, pictures ratings and EMG results.

q22.value: For EMG signal registration, data pre-processing and analysis, Biopac AcqKnowledge software will be used. The timestamps of stimulus presentation will be related to the EMG data. Movement artifacts will be excluded from the analyses.

q24.value: The correlations of general disgust and food disgust measures between freegans and non-freegans (H5a) and between the experienced freegans and beginners (H5b) will be compared in order to explore the moderating role of experience in the relation between food and general disgust in freegans. We will also examine the correlations of the DES subscales with EMG measures (H4). Moreover, on the basis of open-ended questions we will learn about freegans' and non-freegans' experiences and motivations.

registration_responses.q3:
Freeganism is a relatively little explored social phenomenon. To date, studies on freeganism and freegans have been concentrated on describing their subculture, worldview and motivations. However, there is little research concerning the emotion that seems crucial in freeganism - disgust. The goal of the current study is to better understand psychophysiological correlates of a freegan lifestyle. We investigate the possible differences between freegans and non-freegans in propensity to feeling and expressing disgust. It is of particular interest whether these differences stem from previous predispositions, enabling freegans to practise dumpster diving, or rather from the dumpster diving practice itself.

Disgust Sensitivity

Disgust is considered a basic emotion, which has probably evolved to protect animals from contact with potentially pathogenic objects (Chapman & Anderson, 2012; Curtis, Aunger, & Rabie, 2004; Ekman, 1999; Jones, 2000). Feelings and behavioural and physiological responses to disgust seem to be universal for all humans (Ekman, 1999), involving avoidance, specific facial expression, increased saliva production, throat constriction or nauseas (Jones, 2000). However, people vary both in propensity to disgust and in the objects eliciting it in them (Curtis et al., 2004; Jones, 2000). Some of the latter are culturally specific (Cornelissen, 2016; Jones, 2000), which implies that disgust, though biologically based and physically experienced, is also socially shaped. Customs, concerns, education or religion influence the perception of certain stimuli as disgusting or not. As an example of education or belief, an object that touched a contaminated surface, but has no visible trace of it, needs the perceiver’s representation of contamination as detrimental particles to elicit disgust (Jones, 2000). Moreover, disgust is associated with moral judgments (Inbar, Pizarro, Iyer, & Haidt, 2012) - it tends to be felt toward objects or behaviours considered non-normative or impure in a given social environment. Reactions to disgust elicitors from both physical and social domains are shaped by individual proneness to experience this emotion, denoted disgust sensitivity (Haidt, McCauley, & Rozin, 1994). 
Disgust sensitivity can be defined as an individual difference in tendency to react with disgust to certain stimuli (Olatunji, Sawchuk, de Jong, & Lohr, 2006). Disgust sensitivity is higher in adults than children, women than men, individuals with higher than lower neuroticism and with than without obsessive-compulsive disorders (Tybur, Çınar, Karinen, & Perone, 2018). It also varies between mothers and childless women with lower disgust sensitivity of mothers (Prokop & Fančovičová, 2016), as well as between individuals with different political orientations with liberals being less sensitive (Inbar et al., 2012). Relationships with vulnerability to disease and pathogenic habitat are not straightforward. On the one hand, higher disgust sensitivity in a pathogen-rich environment might reduce the risk of infection. On the other hand, probability of contact with pathogens is nevertheless so high that developing tolerance or resistance may result more adaptive than mechanism leading to their avoidance (Tybur et al., 2018). It may also be the case that the differences between groups more and less vulnerable to pathogens only concern some domains of disgust sensitivity and not others (Fessler, Eng, & Navarrete, 2005; Tybur & Lieberman, 2016). 
Although the construct of disgust sensitivity can be divided into disgust in many domains, the number and characteristics of these domains vary across research (cf. Fergus & Valentiner, 2009; Haidt et al., 1994; Olatunji et al., 2006; Olatunji et al., 2007; Petrowski et al., 2011; Tybur, Lieberman, & Griskevicius, 2009). Olatunji and colleagues (2006) in their Disgust Emotion Scale distinguished five disgust domains: Animals, Injections and Blood Draws, Mutilation and Death, Smells, Rotting Foods. Their scale has demonstrated satisfactory reliability and convergent validity shown by positive correlations with respective subscales of Haidt et al.’s (1994) Disgust Scale.

Psychophysiology of Disgust

Apart from declarative measures, behavioural and psychophysiological ones are also utilised in research on disgust and disgust sensitivity. Among the behavioural methods, participant-determined time of exposure to a given object may be used as an index of disgust (Rozin, Haidt, McCauley, Dunlop, & Ashmore, 1999). The psychophysiological methods include heart rate and skin conductance response measures, as well as electromyography (Stark, Walter, Schienle, & Vaitl, 2005; Vrana, 1993). Stark et al. (2005) observed heart rate deceleration and increased skin conductance following exposure to disgusting stimuli,, compared to neutral conditions. Specific facial muscles are also involved in this psychophysiological response (Vrana, 1993). Electromyography (EMG) allows to measure their activity, thus providing a reliable index of experienced emotion (Fridlund & Cacioppo, 1986).
The muscles engaged in the facial expression of disgust are Corrugator supercilii and Levator labii (Vrana, 1993). Corrugator supercilii participates in the expression of general emotional negativity, causing brow knitting, characteristic also to anger (Vrana, 1993). Levator labii, however, seems specific to disgust, being responsible for raising the upper lip and wrinkling the nasal region (Stark et al., 2005; Vrana, 1993).

Freeganism

The name freeganism is a combination of words free and veganism and means an eating habit and a worldview based on valuing food and disapproving of its wastefulness and of consumerism (Black, 2012; Lindeman, 2012). Also called dumpster diving, scavenging or skipping, freeganism consists in finding, eating and sharing food disposed of by others (Gleizes, 2014; Sapała, 2019). It is considered an environmental movement which opposes to ‘food-for-profit’ system resulting in food excess and waste (Barnard, 2016; Carolsfeld, Erikson, 2013; Cornelissen, 2016). Besides, it may be viewed as a commonsensical way to obtain food, saving money (Cornelissen, 2016; Sapała, 2019).
Most often freegans seek edible food in grocery markets’ and supermarkets’ waste bins (Barnard, 2016; Cornelissen, 2016; Sapała, 2019). Physical contact with mixed dregs, rot and mould may evoke disgust. For freegans, however, ‘ugly isn’t a problem’ (Carolsfeld & Erikson, 2013, p. 256) - they seem not to perceive dirty, bruised or otherwise non market-standard food as disgusting (Carolsfeld & Erikson, 2013). This is in line with the finding that food disgust may be a good predictor of eating behaviour: positive correlation was found between food disgust and food wasting (Ammann, Hartmann, & Siegrist, 2018; Egolf, Siegrist, & Hartmann, 2018).
Not only leftovers themselves, but also the cultural taboo over waste  may elicit disgust toward freeganism (Cornelissen, 2016; Gleizes, 2014; Nguyen, Chen, & Mukherjee, 2014). According to Nguyen et al. (2014), freegans are often stigmatized as contaminated and dirty. In their qualitative study the authors showed that freegans who identify themselves with the values and ideals their group follows (e.g., anti-consumerism or environmental protection) can establish a reverse stigma, attributing moral inferiority to the majority of a consumerist society. Thus, they do not perceive dumpster diving disgusting as it fulfils the ethical values their group believes in (Gleizes, 2014; Nguyen et al., 2014).

Preselection or Experience?

On the one hand, Cornelissen (2016) argues that dumpster diving is (sub)culturally learned and that by ideational and linguistic means such as redefinition freegans seem to be able to ‘turn distaste into taste’ (Cornelissen, 2016, p. 501) and to minimize their disgust for dumpster diving. On the other hand, according to Rozin, Haidt and McCauley (2008), food disgust sensitivity appears quite stable throughout adulthood, which suggests that people who become freegans may be predisposed to it by a previously lower level of disgust sensitivity.
Evidence from studies on disgust in medical students does not bring unequivocal conclusions, either. Rozin (2008) observed that first year students’ specific disgust sensitivity to death and body envelope violation diminished after experiencing cadaver dissections, while other domains of disgust sensitivity remained unchanged. People deciding to study medicine may, however, be already less propense to disgust than others, as Consendine, Yu and Windsor’s (2013) study indicates. The authors revealed that disgust sensitivity measured during an introductory university course in human behaviour predicted the students’ intentions to choose medicine, nursing or pharmacy for their major: more disgust sensitive individuals were more likely to choose pharmacy over medicine or nursing. Possibly both processes form part of the relationship between disgust sensitivity and studying medicine. Individuals with lower disgust sensitivity may choose career that exposes them to more disgust elicitors, which, in turn, further diminish their sensitivity to disgust (Consendine et al., 2013). In the current study we would like to address this question in freegans’ case.

Current Research

To the best of our knowledge, there has been no published psychological or psychophysiological research on freegans’ disgust. The first objective of this study is to examine the relationship between disgust sensitivity and freeganism. The second objective is to explore possible mechanisms of the potential lower disgust sensitivity in freegans, especially the interplay between preselection and experience in freegan activity. Furthermore, we also plan to explore the role of freegan in-group identification. Both declarative and psychophysiological methods (EMG) will be used in the measurement of disgust.
We are planning to investigate the following research questions:
1) Are freegans less disgust sensitive than their non-freegan peers? And if so, are freegans less disgust sensitive than their non-freegan peers in general or only when it comes to food and smell disgust?
2) Does lower disgust sensitivity seem to be more a cause or an effect of becoming a freegan?
a) Are experienced freegans less disgust sensitive than beginners?
b) Is the relationship between food and smell disgust sensitivity and other types of disgust sensitivity weaker in experienced freegans than in beginners and non-freegans?
3) Is there a relationship between freegans’ in-group identification and disgust sensitivity?
registration_responses.q4:
Main hypotheses

1) Freegans will show lower disgust sensitivity than their non-freegan peers.
Alternative 1a) Lower general sensitivity (three DES subscales, general disgust pictures ratings and EMG reactions) – suggests self-selection.
Alternative 1b) Lower only food and smell sensitivity (two subscales from DES, food pictures) but not others (not three subscales or general disgust pictures) – suggests influence of experience.
2) More experienced freegans will have lower food and smell disgust sensitivity than less experienced freegans – suggests influence of experience.
3) Stronger identified freegans will have lower disgust sensitivity.

Other tentative hypotheses

4) Correlation for food and smell DES with pictures ratings and EMG reactions will be stronger than correlation for other DES subscales with EMG.
5) Correlations between food and smell disgust sensitivity (averaged two DES subscales) and other types of disgust sensitivity (averaged remaining three DES subscales) will be weaker in freegans than non-freegans (4a) and in experienced freegans than in beginners (4b) – suggests influence of experience.

registration_responses.q11:
In order to select appropriate stimuli and examine properties of our translation of DES, we conducted a pre-test. Participants were recruited via social media and were aimed to have similar demographic characteristics to the planned main sample. We acquired data from 49 participants (41 women, Mage = 22.49, SD = 3.45).
 The pre-test Internet survey contained our translation of DES and 23 images depicting unpleasant food, which were rated by participants for disgust (and exploratorily for edibility) on 5-point Likert-type scales from 1 - no disgust at all to 5 - extreme disgust (and from 1 - completely inedible to 5 - completely edible). The pictures were also rated for valence and arousal on 9-point Self-Assessment Manikin (SAM) scales, in which the numbers corresponded to pictures showing manikins in emotional states of different intensity from 1 of low intensity to 9 of high intensity. SAM scales were included because they are typically used in IAPS pictures assessment (Bradley & Lang, 2007; Lang, Bradley, & Cuthbert, 2008). Other pictures that we are planning to use are from the IAPS database (1111, 1274, 3019, 9008 9031, 9043, 9290, 9300, 9302, 9322, 9340, 9373) and were examined for their disgust-inducing properties in other studies (Borg, Jong, & Schultz, 2010; Van Hooff, Devue, Vieweg, & Theeuwes, 2013). Finally, participants were asked for demographic information.
From the 23 food pictures, 12 pictures with highest mean disgust ratings were selected for the main study. Our food stimuli mean disgust rating was M = 2.34 on the 5-point scale and the ratings ranged from M = 2.29 to M = 3.88 meaning that they were slightly to moderately disgusting. They were descriptively less disgusting than the pictures from IAPS that we are planning to use as general disgust stimuli. In Van Hooff et al.’s (2013) study the latter were rated on average as very disgusting: M = 4.03 on a similar 5-point scale. This is understandable as our pictures were showing “only” partly rotten food or food with insects on it and the pictures in Van Hooff were showing, for example, bloody organs or dirty toilets.
Our food pictures’ mean valence ranged from M = 1.92 to M = 3.12 on the 9-point SAM scale meaning that they were perceived as unpleasant. The selected disgusting food stimuli’s valence seems comparable to the general disgust stimuli selected from the IAPS, mean valence of which ranged from M = 2.24 to M = 3.38 on a similar scale in previous studies (Lang et al., 2008). Mean arousal of our food stimuli ranged from M = 2.98 to M = 5.20 on the 9-point scale, which means the pictures evoked low to medium arousal and were descriptively less arousing than the selected pictures from the IAPS used in previous disgust studies where mean arousal ranged from M = 4.40 to M = 6.30 (Lang et al., 2008).
The food pictures were also exploratorily examined on perceived edibility. The 12 pictures selected on the basis of disgust ratings were rated as, on average, inedible, M = 1.70 on a 5-point scale, ratings ranging from M = 1.14 to M = 2.36.
	The translated DES’s reliability was satisfactory with a Cronbach’s α = 0.76 for the whole scale. The subscales’ reliability ranged from α = 0.67 (Animals) to α = 0.91 (Rotting Food). 
Participants’ disgust sensitivity measured by DES was moderately positively correlated with reported disgust elicited by the pictures, r = 0.62. Rotting Food and Smell subscales’ relation to disgust evoked by the pictures was, r = 0.71 and r = 0.56, respectively. 
	In conclusion, the pre-test allowed to select stimuli for the main study, to acknowledge the translated Disgust Emotion Scale as satisfactorily reliable and to observe an expected correlation of DES and pictures evaluation.
registration_responses.q14: To achieve statistical power at the level of 0,8 with alpha error rate = 0,05, sample size of 63 participants was calculated using powerandsamplesize.com.
registration_responses.q22: For EMG signal registration, data pre-processing and analysis, Biopac AcqKnowledge software will be used. The timestamps of stimulus presentation will be related to the EMG data. Movement artifacts will be excluded from the analyses.
registration_responses.q24: The correlations of general disgust and food disgust measures between freegans and non-freegans (H5a) and between the experienced freegans and beginners (H5b) will be compared in order to explore the moderating role of experience in the relation between food and general disgust in freegans. We will also examine the correlations of the DES subscales with EMG measures (H4). Moreover, on the basis of open-ended questions we will learn about freegans' and non-freegans' experiences and motivations.

registration_responses.q8.question: Between-subject design: groups of freegans vs non-freegans will be compared.
registration_responses.q12.question:
We plan to acquire data from 60 participants with normal or corrected-to-normal vision: 30 freegans and 30 non-freegans with similar demographic characteristics. As the studied group is very specific and not publicly visible, participants will be recruited via social media groups, snowballing and personal contacts. The study will take place in the laboratory of psychophysiology at the Faculty of Psychology, University of Warsaw and is planned to last about 30 minutes. On entering the lab participants will sign an informed consent. Then they will have their skin prepared and electrodes placed. They will be seated in front of a computer screen. The programmed procedure will start after the experimenter leaves the room.
Participants will have activity of Corrugator supercilii and Levator labii measured with EMG, while watching on a computer screen 12 disgust-inducing pictures from IAPS (International Affective Picture System; Lang, Bradley, & Cuthbert, 2008) and 12 pictures showing unattractive food. The latter were pre-tested for their disgust-inducing properties (see the Pre-test and selection of stimuli section above). The pictures will be presented in random order, using MediaLab software. Each of the pictures will be preceded by a three- or six-second fixation mark and displayed for 6 seconds. Silver-silver chloride (Ag-AgCl) surface electrodes will be used, with 0.25 cm diameter detection surfaces and 1 cm diameter housings. As Fridlund and Cacioppo (1986) recommend, the space between two electrodes in a pair will be about 1 cm. The electrodes measuring Corrugator supercilii activity will be placed above the brow: one on an imaginary vertical line above the inner corner of the eye and the other lateral and slightly superior to the first. The electrodes measuring Levator labii activity will be situated 1 cm lateral to the nostril baseline: one 0.5 cm below the nostril and the other superior and slightly lateral to the first. Ground electrode, with 0.5 cm diameter detection surface and 1.5 cm diameter housing, will be located in the middle of the forehead (Fridlund, Cacioppo, 1986). Electrodes, glaired with EEG gel, will be placed on cleaned skin. Impedances, examined using portable impedance checker, should not be higher than 10 kΩ.
	Besides of the EMG measurement, participants will rate how much disgusted they feel about each of the pictures from 1 - no disgust at all to 5 - extreme disgust.
	Second task will be to complete Disgust Emotion Scale (DES; Olatunji et al., 2006) in Polish translation, which has been examined in a pilot study and (for freegan participants) a Polish adaptation of Identification Scale adjusted to freegans (Cameron, 2004; general Polish adaptation by Bilewicz & Wójcik, 2010). Freegan participants will also be asked how long they have been freegans, how often they go dumpster diving and how many times approximately they went dumpster diving. Furthermore, they will be asked questions concerning quality and intensity of freegan experience and motivations for dumpster diving. In the non-freegans’ case, the open-ended question will concern their knowledge and interest in freeganism.
Then they will be presented 7 pictures from IAPS showing young animals, aiming to abreact the exposure to previous unpleasant stimuli. After the programmed procedure will end, they will call the experimenter and have the electrodes removed. Finally, they will be debriefed about the aims of the study and thanked for participation.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Both general and food disgust sensitivity will be assessed with three measures: two declarative and one psychophysiological (EMG; described in the Data collection procedures section). The declarative measures will include pictures ratings from 1 - no disgust at all to 5 - extreme disgust and results on Disgust Emotion Scale (DES; Olatunji et al., 2006 in our pretested translation). DES consists of 30 items pertaining to five subscales. The instruction is to rate how much disgust one would feel if exposed to a given item, e.g. ‘Photos of wounded soldiers’, ‘A pile of rotting lettuce’. The responses are given on 5-point Likert-type scale from 1 - no disgust at all to 5 - extreme disgust.
General disgust sensitivity will be indicated by the result on three non-food-related subscales of DES: Animals,  Injections and Blood Draws, Mutilation and Death; ratings of disgust-inducing pictures and Corrugator supercilii and Levator labii reactions to disgust-inducing pictures. Correspondingly, food disgust sensitivity will be indicated by the result in Rotting Food and Smell subscales of DES, ratings of pictures showing unattractive food and Corrugator supercilii and Levator labii reactions to pictures showing unattractive food.
	Experience with freeganism will be measured with a yes/no question, filtering the subsequent questions. Freegans’ in-group identification will be measured with the Identification Scale adjusted to freegans (Cameron, 2004; general Polish adaptation by Bilewicz & Wójcik, 2010). The scale comprises 6 items (sample item: ‘I feel strong ties to other [ingroup members]’). The responses are given on 5-point Likert-type scale from 1 - strongly disagree to 5 - strongly agree.
Freegans’ experience in dumpster diving will be investigated with questions about: declared time since starting (in months), frequency (how many times per month) and number of dumpster diving experiences, the type of containers frequented, kinds of food taken and usage of gloves. Their motivation for freeganism will be explored with an open-ended question about how and why they started dumpster diving. Non-freegans will be asked an open-ended question about their knowledge what freeganism is and whether they would be willing to try it, instead.
	We will also control age, gender, education, place of residence (urban or rural) and political orientation (one-item seven-point scale from 1 - strongly left-wing to 7 - strongly right-wing).
registration_responses.q19.question:
In order to examine the H1, we will compare freegans’ and non-freegans’ results in DES and its subscales, their pictures ratings and their Corrugator and Levator activity. ANCOVA will be used for each measure, controlling for demographic variables.
	To examine whether food disgust decreases with gaining freegan experience (H2) we will investigate correlations between measures of experience and DES Rotting Food and Smell subscales, pictures ratings and Corrugator and Levator activity.
	To test the H3, Pearson correlations will be calculated to examine the relations between in-group identification and disgust sensitivity measured by DES, pictures ratings and EMG results.

q4.value:
1. Donors who provide PII before indicating their donation amount will donate a higher amount than donors who provide PII after indicating their donation amount.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a 2 by 2 between-subjects design, with the first factor as the order of PII and the second factor as the relevance of PII to the act of charitable giving.

q9.value: We will use block randomisation, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the four blocks.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Turkprime in the Monday morning (Feb 24, 2020). Participants will be paid $0.5 for finishing our experiment. Participants should be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: We have four conditions for this experiment. We aim to collect 150 responses for each cell, and thus our target sample size is 600 participants.

question.value: We manipulated two variables in this study. First, the order of PII will be manipulated by changing the order of providing PII and indicating donation amount; specifically, in one condition, participants will be required to provide PII before indicating donation amount, while in the other condition, participants will be asked to provide PII after indicating donation amount. Second, the relevance of PII to the act of charitable giving will be manipulated by different reasons for participants to provide PII; specifically, in one condition, participants will be required to provide PII for donation purpose while in the other condition, participants will be asked to provide PII for differentiating between human participants and robot participants.

The single outcome variable will be indicated donation amount. We will ask participants to imagine that they win a bonus of $10 and think about how much they decide to donate to a charity by specifically measuring "Please indicate the amount of your contribution ($) to EDF by sliding the scale (on a sliding scale of 1-10)."

In addition, we will measure some demographic variables.
We do not create an index. The indicated donation amount is our key variable.
We will use a 2X2 two way-ANOVA to analyse our results.

q20.value:
In terms of PII order, PII-after will be coded as "1" and PII-before will be coded as "2".
In terms of PII relevance to the act of charitable giving, PII-relevant will be coded as "1" and PII-irrelevant will be codes as "2".

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 (sometime p<.1 for marginal significance) criteria for determining if the two-way ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly or marginally significantly different from those pelted if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: We set an attention check in our experiment. We will exclude those who fail the attention check.

q23.value: We will exclude those whose data is incomplete.

attributes.title: Psychological responses to 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) outbreak
attributes.description: In order to improve our understanding of public reaction to epidemic outbreak, the present study examined temporal relationships between psychological responses toward 2019-nCoV and attitudinal responses to crisis management. A longitudinal design was employed. It is hypothesized that changes of behavioural and affective responses with the pandemic develops are associated with crisis management appraisal.

attributes.title: Efficacy and Safety of Chinese Herbal Medicine for Ulcerative Colitis: a systematic review and meta-analysis Protocol

q1.value: Efficacy and Safety of Chinese Herbal Medicine for Ulcerative Colitis: a systematic review and meta-analysis Protocol

q2.value: Qiaobo Ye, ZhipengHu, MaoyiYang, Kaihua Qin, Yingguang Zhou

q3.value: Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic non-specific intestinal inflammatory disease, which is characterized by continuous and diffuse inflammatory response of colonic mucosa. The most common clinical symptoms are diarrhea and mucopurulent bloody stool, which can be accompanied by abdominal pain. The etiology of UC is not fully elucidated. At present, standardized treatment drugs such as sulfasalazine, mesalazine, glucocorticoid and immunosuppressant can effectively alleviate the onset of UC, but they are faced with such problems as long medication cycle, more adverse reactions and decreased compliance of patients. Traditional Chinese medicine has a long history and rich experience in the treatment of UC. There are unique advantages in reducing recurrence of UC and improving patients' quality of life. In recent years, many researches in the treatment of UC with TCM have been conducted, but there are some defects in the design, management and report quality of the trial, so the exact efficacy remains unknown. Therefore, this study aims to evaluate the therapeutic effects of traditional Chinese medicine on UC, in order to provide an evidence support for clinical practice.

q4.value: If Chinese herbal medicine is effective for ulcerative colitis, the patients' condition will be relieved

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Three English databases including PubMed, EMBASE and Cochrane Library and three Chinese databases including China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), Wanfang Data knowledge service platform and VIP information resource integration service platform will be searched from its inception without language limitation. In addition, we will search Google Scholar and Baidu scholar for more related researches. And above all, the Chinese Clinical Trial Registration Center (ChiCTR) and clinical trials.gov will be searched. The combination of MeSH terms and free words will be adopted by us for database searching.
We will mainly use the following terms to search: ("chinese herbal medicine" OR "Chinese Herbal Medicine" OR "Drugs, Chinese Herbal" OR "Chinese Herbal" OR "Chinese herbal" OR "Medicine, Chinese Traditional" OR "Traditional Chinese Medicine" OR "traditional chinese medicine" OR "Traditional Chinese medicine decoction" ) AND ("Ulcerative Colitis" OR"Colitis, Ulcerative" OR "Idiopathic Proctocolitis"OR"Colitis Gravis"OR"Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Ulcerative Colitis Type"). Search strategy would be revised repeatedly according to the actual situation.
Two methodologically trained researchers will read the titles, abstract and full texts of the studies and will select the researches according to the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Then two researchers will check the results with each other. Final decisions on eligibility will be made through consensus, if there are discrepancies.
Data from included studies will then be extracted into a Microsoft Excel data extraction form.
For each study, the following data will be extracted: the first authors of the article, the year of publication, the interventions used in experimental group, the interventions used in the control group, the course of treatment, the course of the disease, the number of patients in each group, the ages and sexes of the patients, outcomes and safety data.
We will contact the corresponding author to request the provision of more detailed data if necessary.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Three English databases including PubMed, EMBASE and Cochrane Library and three Chinese databases including China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), Wanfang Data knowledge service platform and VIP information resource integration service platform will be searched from its inception without language limitation. In addition, we will search Google Scholar and Baidu scholar for more related researches. And above all, the Chinese Clinical Trial Registration Center (ChiCTR) and clinical trials.gov will be searched. The combination of MeSH terms and free words will be adopted by us for database searching.
We will mainly use the following terms to search: ("chinese herbal medicine" OR "Chinese Herbal Medicine" OR "Drugs, Chinese Herbal" OR "Chinese Herbal" OR "Chinese herbal" OR "Medicine, Chinese Traditional" OR "Traditional Chinese Medicine" OR "traditional chinese medicine" OR "Traditional Chinese medicine decoction" ) AND ("Ulcerative Colitis" OR"Colitis, Ulcerative" OR "Idiopathic Proctocolitis"OR"Colitis Gravis"OR"Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Ulcerative Colitis Type"). Search strategy would be revised repeatedly according to the actual situation.
All Chinese herbal medicines can be used for trails, and there is no limit to the methods used, including oral administration, enema, fumigation, etc.
If the treatment group uses Chinese herbal medicine combined with conventional drugs to treat ulcerative colitis, the control group must also use the same conventional drugs.
The patients in control group can be treated with placebo or conventional therapy.

q13.value: Three English databases including PubMed, EMBASE and Cochrane Library and three Chinese databases including China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), Wanfang Data knowledge service platform and VIP information resource integration service platform will be searched from its inception without language limitation. In addition, we will search Google Scholar and Baidu scholar for more related researches. And above all, the Chinese Clinical Trial Registration Center (ChiCTR) and clinical trials.gov will be searched. The combination of MeSH terms and free words will be adopted by us for database searching.

question.value:
main outcomes：
1. Total clinical effective rate.
2. Incidence of adverse events.
3. Disease activity index (modified Mayo score).
4. Results of enteroscopy (Baron score).
5. Mucosa (geboes index score).
6. Serum inflammatory cytokines (TNF - α, IL-6, IL-10).
7. Other results related to ulcerative colitis will be included in our study.
 Before and after treatment, clinical observation, scale score, laboratory test and enteroscopy were performed. There is no limit to the measurement of results.
Additional outcomes：
1. Recurrence rate. 2. Effective rate of symptoms

The heterogeneity of the data will be investigated using Cochran's χ2 test and the I2 statistic. Statistical heterogeneity is considered to exist for values of P < 0.05, and the degree of heterogeneity is determined by the value of I2, with values > 50% being indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
If there is heterogeneity between the data, then the random effect model will used. If there is no significant heterogeneity between the data, the fixed effect model will used.
For the dichotomous data, the Mantel-Haenszel (M-H) method will be used to calculate risk ratio (RR) and 95% confidence interval (CI). For continuous data, the inverse variance (IV) method will be used to calculate mean difference (MD) and 95% CI.
If more than ten studies are included, then a meta-regression and publication bias assessment will be carried out.
In addition, a sensitivity analysis will also be conducted to evaluate the stability of the results in the software Stata.
Finally, the GRADE method will be used to evaluate the quality of the evidence.

attributes.title: Review Protocol for the Systematic Mapping of Well-Being in Lawyers, Accountants, Investment Bankers, and Management Consultants, and an In-Depth Synthesis Review of Lawyers’ Well-Being
attributes.description: Rising reports of poor well-being in the legal profession have been noted in multiple countries and jurisdictions. With increased global concerns about lawyer well-being, the amount of practitioner and academic literature has also increased. However, the literature remains fragmented and disparate, with a lack of comprehensive review in this area. A systematic scoping (mapping) of the literature is therefore needed to characterise the current body of knowledge, identify key concepts and contexts thought to influence lawyer well-being, and collate this knowledge in the form of a searchable database. The creation of this new knowledge will enable a synthesis review to be performed to integrate and analyse the available evidence and perspectives published globally within this emerging field. The review will also systematically scope the literature concerning well-being in three other professional groups which operate within similar work environments to lawyers, namely accounting, investment banking, and management consulting. By including these professional groups in the review, an important source of knowledge will be created, against which the well-being of lawyers can be compared and synthesised. This review will adopt a two-staged approach. The first stage will scope and map the current literature using systematic mapping methodology and stakeholder involvement. Using outputs from the systematic mapping stage, an in-depth thematic synthesis review of lawyers’ well-being will then be conducted.

summary.value:

attributes.title: Functional Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy during Social Processing
attributes.description:
This study seeks to understand neurobiological functions involved in processing social information, such as facial expressions, tone of voice, and body language. We use neuroimaging technology in the form of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) to investigate changes in brain chemicals while people view and process such social information, specifically facial expressions. It is important to understand differences in brain functionality associated with social information processing, so that we can better support people that have difficulties in this area, such as those with autism or schizophrenia spectrum disorder.

Participants will attend two testing sessions at Swinburne University of Technology, separated by a 1-hour break:
1)	clinical and social processes assessment, and  resting and functional MRS;
2)     resting and functional MRS, and functional MRI.

q1.value: Functional Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy during Social Processing

q3.value:
We will conduct the first study to investigate changes in excitatory glutamate and inhibitory GABA neurotransmitter concentrations during a social processing task, as well as the relationship between glutamate and GABA concentrations and social processing ability. Social processing ability will be assessed using tools outlined by the gold-standard National Institute of Mental Health Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) of Social Processes (Insel, 2010). We will also investigate the extent to which glutamate changes during the social processing task are associated with autism and schizophrenia spectrum traits. 

Glutamate and GABA concentrations will be quantified from the right superior temporal sulcus (STS), a well validated social processing region (Deen, Koldewyn, Kanwisher, & Saxe, 2015; Pitcher, Dilks, Saxe, Triantafyllou, & Kanwisher, 2011), and a control region in the visual cortex for comparison. Furthermore, we will establish the relationship between functional glutamate and GABA and brain activity associated with social processing as indicated by blood oxygen level depletion (BOLD) signal, measured using functional MRI (fMRI).

**Primary objective:**   
To investigate the neurochemical processes involved in social processing among healthy adults using a novel neuroimaging technique, fMRS; specifically, changes in Glx and GABA concentrations in the social processing regions of right STS.

**Secondary objectives:** 
1)	To investigate the relationship between task-based glutamate and GABA concentrations and social processing ability, as well as autism and schizophrenia spectrum traits;
2)	To establish the relationship between functional Glx and GABA and BOLD signal during social processing;
3)	To identify differences in functional Glx and GABA and BOLD signal during social processing between the current 3T Siemens Trio MRI scanner at Swinburne Neuroimaging and the new 3T Siemens Prisma.

Forty healthy adults aged 18-40 (20 male, 20 female) will be recruited for in this study. Male and female participants will be matched on age and handedness, and will be free from psychiatric (e.g., schizophrenia, depression), neurological (e.g., epilepsy, seizures) and genetic (e.g., Fragile x syndrome) conditions.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Primary outcome: Functional MRS
2 (voxel: STS, V1) x 3 (task: rest, face, object) within subjects design, with Glx and GABA as the dependent variables.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q13.value: Forty healthy adults aged 18-40 (20 male, 20 female) will be recruited for in this study. Male and female participants will be matched on age and handedness, and will be free from psychiatric (e.g., schizophrenia, depression), neurological (e.g., epilepsy, seizures) and genetic (e.g., Fragile x syndrome) conditions. Ten of the participants that attend the first testing session (5 male, 5 female) will be asked to return for a second MRI scan following the upgrade of the MRI scanner at SNI to a Siemens 3T Prisma, in order to test the replicability of the results between the original Siemens 3T Trio and the new Prisma.

q14.value: Based on conservative estimates to assess our primary outcome: change in glutamate and GABA concentrations between REST and FUNCTIONAL, for a repeated measures within factors ANOVA to detect a small-to-moderate effect (f = .2) across 4 task repetitions at a .8 power and statistical threshold of alpha = .05, 36 participants are required. We will recruit 40 to account for participant exclusion due to poor neuroimaging data.

question.value:
Participants will first watch a white cross on a black background to collect resting Glx and GABA concentrations from the STS. Then, two functional MRS (fMRS) scans will be conducted, where participants will watch a series of dynamic faces or objects. These fMRS tasks will be repeated twice, once to collect data from the social STS region, and once to collect data from the visual control region. 

Functional MRI (fMRI) scans will be conducted to identify whole-brain activation in response to emotional faces compared to objects.

To measure participants RDoC Social Processes, three gold standard measures will be completed: 1) the Social Responsiveness Scale (SRS; Constantino & Gruber, 2005, SRS-2; 2012), a reliable 65-item measure of symptom severity across five autism symptom domains: Social Awareness, Social Motivation, Social Cognition, Social Communication, and Repetitive Behaviours/Restricted Interests. 2) the Reading the Mind in the Eyes task (RME; Baron-Cohen, Wheelwright, Hill, et al., 2001), a 36-item computerised task that measures perception and understanding of others mental state through the assessment an actor’s eyes. 3) Penn Emotion Recognition task (PER; Gur et al., 2002), a computerised task that includes 40 colour photographs of static faces expressing 4 basic emotions (happiness, sadness, anger, or fear) and neutral expressions.

The following measures will be used for exploratory analyses:
Autism traits will be measured using the Autism Spectrum Quotient (AQ; Baron-Cohen, Wheelwright, Skinner, et al., 2001), a 50-item self-report questionnaire designed to quantify autistic traits in the typically developing population. 
Schizophrenia spectrum traits will be measured using the Community Assessment of Psychic Experience (CAPE; Stefanis et al., 2002), a 42-item self-report scale measuring the presence of positive psychotic experiences, negative psychotic experiences, and depressive experiences that an individual may have experienced over the last 12 months (Stefanis et al., 2002). 
The Depression, Anxiety, Stress Scale (DASS-21; Lovibond and Lovibond, 1995) is a 21-item scale measuring the presence and severity of depression, anxiety and stress.

To assess differences in Glx and GABA concentrations between rest, faces and objects tasks for STS and V1, two 2 (voxel) x 3 (task) repeated measures analyses of variance (rmANOVA) will be conducted. In order to control for family-wise error (two metabolites), false discovery rate (FDR) correction will be applied for the two comparisons. 

To investigate the extent to which task-based Glx and GABA concentrations are predictive of social processing ability (RME, SRS, and PER) and autism and schizotypal trait domains, multiple regression analyses will be used. In the event that assumptions for parametric statistical tests are not met, non-parametric alternatives will be used.

Finally, to investigate the difference in fMRS outcomes (Glx and GABA concentrations during rest, faces and objects tasks) between the Siemens 3T Trio and Prisma scanners, two 2 (scanner) x 2 (voxel) x 3 (task) rmANOVAs will be conducted, controlling for FDR.

q20.value: Data will first be screened for suitability to parametric statistical analysis using Shapiro-Wilk tests for skewness/kurtosis. Positive skew will be managed by applying a square-root or exponential transform.

q22.value: Participant data will be excluded from analysis in cases where MRS data are of poor quality (based in water linewidths and signal to noise ratio), and in cases where the Cramer-Rao Lower Bound is greater than 20%.

q23.value: The demographics, AQ, CAPE, DASS, RME and PER are computer-administered questionnaires/tasks, thus it is unlikely there will missing or spurious data. The SRS is a standardised questionnaire, and will be checked following participant completion to ensure all questions were answered. After initial data entry, a second researcher will confirm it is correct to avoid data entry errors.

registration_responses.q19.question:
To assess differences in Glx and GABA concentrations between rest, faces and objects tasks for STS and V1, two 2 (voxel) x 3 (task) repeated measures analyses of variance (rmANOVA) will be conducted. In order to control for family-wise error (two metabolites), false discovery rate (FDR) correction will be applied for the two comparisons. 

To investigate the extent to which task-based Glx and GABA concentrations are predictive of social processing ability (RME, SRS, and PER) and autism and schizotypal trait domains, multiple regression analyses will be used. In the event that assumptions for parametric statistical tests are not met, non-parametric alternatives will be used.

Finally, to investigate the difference in fMRS outcomes (Glx and GABA concentrations during rest, faces and objects tasks) between the Siemens 3T Trio and Prisma scanners, two 2 (scanner) x 2 (voxel) x 3 (task) rmANOVAs will be conducted, controlling for FDR.

attributes.title: Evaluation Schema and Investment to Ventures in Emerging Technology Fields

q1.value: Evaluation Criteria Consensus and Investment to Ventures in Emerging Technology Fields: Testing Multiple Industries/Technology Fields

q3.value: This paper theorizes that consensus in evaluation criteria for a technology will make investors more willing to invest in ventures in that technology field. In this experiment, we test whether the effect of consensus in evaluation criteria for varies across industries and technology fields with different levels of nascence.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Consensus in evaluation criteria for a technology has a positive effect on investment to ventures that uses that technology.
Hypothesis 2: The positive effect of consensus in evaluation criteria on investment is positively moderated by the nascence of the technology such that when the technology is more nascent the effect of evaluation criteria consensus is stronger/more positive, compared to when the technology is less nascent.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: We have a 3-factor 2 (evaluation criteria consensus: high versus low) *2 (industry nascence: high versus low) *2 (technology nascence: high versus low) between-subject design.

q9.value: Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the eight conditions by Qualtrics, the survey platform.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from an online platform, in particular Prolific. Participants will be paid $0.60 for their participation. We recruit participants with managerial experiences.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 960 participants (120 for each condition).

question.value: We manipulated (a) the level of evaluation criteria consensus, (b) industry nascence level, and (c) technology field nascence level. The two levels for all three variables are: high versus low.

Outcome variables: 
1. Investment amount:
 • How much of the $2,000,000 will you invest in this firm? 
2. Willingness to invest (1=strongly disagree to 7=strongly agree)
• I am willing to invest money in this firm. 
• I believe that monetary investment in this firm will yield good returns. 
• This firm presents a great opportunity for investment.

Hypothesis testing (cross-condition comparison): t-test and ANOVA.  
Manipulation check: t-test. 

Manipulation check items: (1=strongly disagree to 7=strongly agree) 
1. Evaluation criteria consensus
• There is consensus about the proper metrics to evaluate GPS/NLP technology. 
• Academics and industry researchers agree on the metrics to evaluate GPS/NLP technology. 
• There is a lot of disagreement over the proper metrics to evaluate GPS/NLP technology. 

2. Industry nascence level:
How mature is the automotive/drone industry?
• The automotive/drone industry is very mature.							
• The automotive/drone industry is very established.						
• The automotive/drone industry is very new.							
• The automotive/drone industry is very nascent.

3. Technology field nascence level
How mature is the GPS/NLP technology?
• The GPS/NLP technology is very mature.							
• The GPS/NLP technology is very established.							
• The GPS/NLP technology is very new.								
• The GPS/NLP technology is very nascent.

q22.value: We will exclude the participants (a) who do not pass the simple attention check questions, (b) who guess the purpose of the study correctly, and (c) who have no investment experience.

q24.value: We are collecting two exploratory variables: perceived technology capability and others’ investment intention. We will test both variables as the mediator in a model where evaluation criteria consensus is the independent variable and investment (intention) is the dependent variable. We will use Hayes’s PROCESS Model 4 with 5,000-time bootstrapping.
